none: Performance at Soldier Field and Northwestern vs. Iowa
Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). School of Music (Contributor)
Intermittent tracking issues, especially around 00:09:40 (General Note)
Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). School of Music
Hindemith, Paul, 1895-1963. Symphonic metamorphosis of themes by Carl Maria von Weber. March

Performances by the Northwestern University Marching Band at Soldier Field and Dyche Stadium. First, the Northwestern University Marching Band performs a halftime show at a Chicago Bears game at Soldier Field in Chicago, Illinois. The performance includes "You are the Sunshine of My Life," "La Fiesta," "South Rampart Street Parade," and "Go U Northwestern." Then the Northwestern University Marching Band performs at the Northwestern Wildcats home game against the University of Iowa Hawkeyes at Dyche Stadium. The University of Iowa Marching Band performs a pregame show. Conducted by Stephen G. Peterson, the Northwestern University Marching Band's pregame performances include "God Bless America," "Go U Northwestern," and the National Anthem. The University of Iowa Marching Band's halftime show features the "Battle Hymn of the Republic" and "1812 Overture." The Northwestern University Marching Band's halftime show features a set of music from 20th century composers including Paul Hindemith's "March from Symphonic Metamorphosis," Leonard Bernstein's "Slava," and Aaron Copland's "Appalachian Spring."

The recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited. Please contact specialcollections@northwestern.edu for more information
Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections API
Homepage at Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections

Digitization of this collection was funded by a generous gift from the family of Music professor and bandleader John Phillip Paynter, who began his musical studies at Northwestern, graduating with a Bachelor of Music degree in 1950 and a Master's in Theory and Composition in 1951. Upon graduation, Paynter joined NU's faculty as the Director of the Marching Band. During his career at Northwestern, Paynter taught classes in band music, conducting, and arranging.
